headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The -- can you -- with the new version of TMOS coming out now, do you anticipate any of the new hardware platforms coming out as well? Do you anticipate the new hardware platforms to gain more share than they otherwise would have or
componenttext: A couple of questions. The -- can you -- with the new version of TMOS coming out now, do you anticipate any of the new hardware platforms coming out as well? Do you anticipate the new hardware platforms to gain more share than they otherwise would have or see some sort of an upgrade across the product portfolio because it would be necessary to get DPI working and then -- and some of the other features in the new versions of TMOS, or is this more of a minor upgrade on TMOS?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: No -- this is John, and maybe Karl could speak after me, but this is very significant in my opinion, on 2 fronts, say, here. First of all, the actual -- we're doing a full appliance refresh. That's a number of significant and new products. And we are goin
componenttext: No -- this is John, and maybe Karl could speak after me, but this is very significant in my opinion, on 2 fronts, say, here. First of all, the actual -- we're doing a full appliance refresh. That's a number of significant and new products. And we are going to see performance increases in those appliances to the tune of about 5x the current performance of the existing systems. So we expect that to definitely create, say, some good growth refresh opportunities and market share with it. We're very, very talented at doing that. And then along with that, we're also coming out with the new version of TMOS that's got a software functionality with things like the firewall, our full layer 3 to layer 7 firewall product that we think is going to be very, very competitive, along with functionality for the SP provider like DPI. So we really believe they are generating -- they have revenue-generating type capabilities.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- if we start looking -- by the way, this is Karl. If we start looking at some of the functionality and the impact with DPI, we have a whole new classification engine that's been built up into the core of TMOS. So that's a very significant chang
componenttext: Yes, the -- if we start looking -- by the way, this is Karl. If we start looking at some of the functionality and the impact with DPI, we have a whole new classification engine that's been built up into the core of TMOS. So that's a very significant change. And then we've done a lot of other under-the-hood changes in TMOS to support other requirements in the search provider market, such as very specific targeted iRules. We've done some other work there with productizing some of the carrier grade NAT features, and a lot of focus on IPv6 and carrying that forward. So there's a lot of work that's been done there. And, obviously, on the security, a lot of the development that's been done there has been extending essentially what's been done in the past, but really productizing things and adding capabilities around rules, having the new rules language and other things that can be applied not only at the network layer, but at the application layer as well, and then having these things all tied together cleanly in the management framework. So it's a very complete and a very big upgrade to what we had previously.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, the verticals seem to move around a little bit. Obviously, telco and tech were down some. Is some of the trepidation going into next quarter? Obviously, it's on a big macro basis, but can we -- is it accurate to say that you were
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, the verticals seem to move around a little bit. Obviously, telco and tech were down some. Is some of the trepidation going into next quarter? Obviously, it's on a big macro basis, but can we -- is it accurate to say that you were more -- I don't to want say worried, but more concerned about some of those verticals, like telco and tech that came down? I know you expect the telco to come down. It was very strong last quarter. But does it look as though those will stay weak going into next quarter? And is that one of the main drivers behind the slightly more conservative guidance?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I'd say it's more overall macro than specifically in the verticals. I mean, typically, our verticals move around depending on projects. And we don't see any significant deterioration in any of the verticals. Obviously, technology has been down somewha
componenttext: No. I'd say it's more overall macro than specifically in the verticals. I mean, typically, our verticals move around depending on projects. And we don't see any significant deterioration in any of the verticals. Obviously, technology has been down somewhat where they have been, quite often, instead of having layer 7 type capabilities, they may have done some of their own work. But that's been a pretty slow process. So nothing really changing in the verticals.

componenttext: A question and a clarification. For the question, can you talk about some of the demand trends you experienced in Europe? It actually looks like the business performed fairly well from both a sequential and year-over-year perspective. I would like to get some additional details regarding where you saw the strength, where you saw the weakness in the region and how you're thinking about Europe and your guidance for the September quarter? And then for the clarification, I was hoping you could discuss how much revenue received from Traffix in the period.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of Europe, it was probably what you would expect. So areas like the U.K. were very strong. France, Germany, the key geographies were pretty solid. Europe has been very out in the lead in terms of security sales as well. That has helped a
componenttext:
Yes. So in terms of Europe, it was probably what you would expect. So areas like the U.K. were very strong. France, Germany, the key geographies were pretty solid. Europe has been very out in the lead in terms of security sales as well. That has helped a lot. And to be fair, it was a pretty easy comparison versus the same quarter a year ago. But generally, we are very, very happy with the way things have been performing.
In terms of Traffix, yes, we did revenue. It wasn't significant. We're actually -- we really view that as part of our ADC, so we're not going to be giving that out. I think that the message I gave last quarter, and it's still the same, though we will see some revenue to Traffix next quarter as we did this quarter. However, we really think that the major opportunity is fiscal 2013.

componenttext: Yes, we saw some very, very large deals across all theaters last quarter and specifically in Americas, we saw 2 very, very significant deals, one from a very large bank, who is also been telling people that they need to figure out ways to reduce cost to adjust themselves to their new revenue models. And they actually invested close to $5 million with us in a refresh opportunity to consolidate. And then we had another very large financial institution in the D.C. area. But also it was actually a competitive replacement that also invested almost $3 million with us. So even in kind of tough times for that vertical, they're spending money where they could see they can gain lots of efficiencies. So I think that was a good reason why we had a good quarter from the finance vertical.

componenttext: On the headcount front, I think we're targeting about 125 in the quarter. Did 100 -- we're looking at 125 again for the next quarter. I know you guys you have puts and takes relative to hitting the bogey on any given quarter. But should we read anything into that 100 versus 125 as it relates to maybe how long you think the kind of a -- the kind of macro pressures might persist?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Definitely, as we went through the quarter, we talk a lot about how we manage expenses as we're watching the quarter unfold. And as we both mentioned in our scripts, in this tougher macro environment, as we watched it size up, we got more cautious with ou
componenttext: Definitely, as we went through the quarter, we talk a lot about how we manage expenses as we're watching the quarter unfold. And as we both mentioned in our scripts, in this tougher macro environment, as we watched it size up, we got more cautious with our hiring, but did continue to hire. And as we look at next quarter with what we think we'll achieve in terms of revenue as you see in the guidance put out there, we think we can absorb the 125. What I'd like to highlight in these comments is that we do want to keep hiring because we want to invest in growth, and we see the opportunity there. But as we've said over and over again, we will invest in a way that protects our operating margin, and we're committed to the 38% level. So I think you won't see our behavior change in how we manage the business week in and week out.

However, as you think about the timing of the next generation of TMOS in conjunction with, obviously, your sweeping appliance refresh, is there any concern relative to maybe demand push out around the timing of those 2 things having to be coinciding a little bit more tightly than historical?

componenttext: No. We -- again, I always -- I've been asked this question probably for about 10 years. [indiscernible] as we should be. And I don't want to come over as complacent, but I feel really, really positive about the way we can manage the new products coming in, typically, in any case, our products -- our existing products are a refresh, they're often redeployed, so we don't often see that. I don't think there's going to be issue there. The key for us is to actually get the roadmap on track and get these growth opportunities out there as soon as possible.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rohit, this is Karl. I just wanted to mention, so in terms of software, when we come out with new versions, we make that available on all of our hardware platforms to the extent that they were able to accept it. So multiple generations of platforms t
componenttext: Yes, Rohit, this is Karl. I just wanted to mention, so in terms of software, when we come out with new versions, we make that available on all of our hardware platforms to the extent that they were able to accept it. So multiple generations of platforms typically can be upgraded to the latest releases. They may not run all features because of whatever limitations they have, but we generally make most available. So -- and that's no different for any large release that we're doing -- this upcoming release is no different than any of other releases that we've done in the past with regards to that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Typically, what we see there is that, obviously, we see customers being cautious with our new release of software, and we had exactly the same with version 9, 10 or 11, we'll see the same coming again. Having said that, one of the drivers to really s
componenttext: Yes. Typically, what we see there is that, obviously, we see customers being cautious with our new release of software, and we had exactly the same with version 9, 10 or 11, we'll see the same coming again. Having said that, one of the drivers to really speed up customers tends to be specific functionality. So if a customer is really specific in terms of the need and what they can benefit from, say DPI, they'll go at it faster. But that will be a pretty natural process.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And with our chassis-based products, too, the nice thing there is that a lot -- our customers are future proved, that is if they need more capacity for the new features, for example, they're able to just add blades to the system quite easily. So th
componenttext: Right. And with our chassis-based products, too, the nice thing there is that a lot -- our customers are future proved, that is if they need more capacity for the new features, for example, they're able to just add blades to the system quite easily. So that's already built into that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then, Rohit, this is Dan Matte. So on the competitive environment front, in the macro stories, we haven't seen really big changes. We've picked up some share actually across the core ADC market. We've seen actually great growth in our virtual addition
componenttext: And then, Rohit, this is Dan Matte. So on the competitive environment front, in the macro stories, we haven't seen really big changes. We've picked up some share actually across the core ADC market. We've seen actually great growth in our virtual additions as well. So I think we've been pretty disruptive on that side of things. Also on the security side, with the performance of our data center firewall and sales on that front, again, we think we're being pretty disruptive in that market. If we look at our win rates, as reported by our sales team, continued to be extremely high out there. So, overall, I think we're sitting quite well.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012

componenttext: And our next question comes from Catharine Trebnick with Northland Securities.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: My question is your use cases for the carrier space, can you go through those? And the other one would be, are there any regions you're seeing any carrier softness in over other regions?
componenttext: My question is your use cases for the carrier space, can you go through those? And the other one would be, are there any regions you're seeing any carrier softness in over other regions?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Karl. We have a number of different areas, use cases that is, in the service provider. Everything from carrier grade NAT to IPv6, like I mentioned earlier to doing things with their -- in their managed services environments, web hosting, those typ
componenttext: This is Karl. We have a number of different areas, use cases that is, in the service provider. Everything from carrier grade NAT to IPv6, like I mentioned earlier to doing things with their -- in their managed services environments, web hosting, those types of things. Optimization, we help optimize, say, video delivery of content or web applications that they're handling. Again, with the signaling traffic, we help scale that. For example, we can scale diameter, set the radius. We also -- now, with our Traffix acquisition, we now have a full signaling, or we call it our STC [ph], but we have now a full Diameter signaling capability, routing capability there. So there's a lot of areas that were leveraged in this. And again, like John is saying earlier, they tend to be project oriented. But it's a pretty big footprint there. And with the new upcoming DPI functionality, we're hoping to expand that footprint and consolidate a lot of functionality that exist in platforms that tend to be around us.

componenttext: I wanted to just get a little bit more clarification, particularly on the financial vertical discussion, quite a big number in what's a tough environment. headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wow, it's the last one. On the last one, I'm not sure if it's 3 to 5 years because that's -- I don't want to make that prediction when it's so far out. But in terms of the virtual ADC, we've now got -- we've now probably got the largest array of solutions
componenttext: Wow, it's the last one. On the last one, I'm not sure if it's 3 to 5 years because that's -- I don't want to make that prediction when it's so far out. But in terms of the virtual ADC, we've now got -- we've now probably got the largest array of solutions out there from a software-only perspective in terms of the ADC-type solutions. In other words, our core LTE product, virtual as well as on the modules as well, security modules, optimization modules. And that's been going extremely well. It's still a small proportion of our business, but a very fast, high percentage growing portion. We see a lot of hybrid sales. So we'll see sales where it's -- as the software version, as well as the system version. And the beauty is that we can manage them similarly, so the customer can mix and match depending on the area. And you're right, cloud is probably the main area of opportunity there. But in terms of going 3 to 5 years, that's a bit tough.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simon, this is Dan. So while we're not prognosticating on the size of the -- that portion of the market, fortunately, there are others who do. And so the target for the virtualized part of the market runs about roughly 10% of the overall market sort
componenttext: Yes, Simon, this is Dan. So while we're not prognosticating on the size of the -- that portion of the market, fortunately, there are others who do. And so the target for the virtualized part of the market runs about roughly 10% of the overall market sort of in that time frame that you're talking about. And so what we're doing about it is, as John said, the sales of our virtual additions are going really well. We're giving our customers versions of our products that they can inject into cloud providers themselves. We have also started our cloud-licensing program, so using the cloud vendors as more of a channel for us so they can take that functionality, if you will, and rent it to their customers on an ongoing basis. So that's really tapping into a customer base that otherwise we -- it will be more difficult for us to address.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about increasing the performance availability on the software ADC side, some of the cloud features? And then how that plays out with selling into some of those technology customers that are doing some of their own work.
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about increasing the performance availability on the software ADC side, some of the cloud features? And then how that plays out with selling into some of those technology customers that are doing some of their own work.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'm going to start. So Kent, this is Dan Matte. There's a couple of things. So one, with the virtual additions themselves, we are going to be increasing the performance. We think we already have great performance within our virtual additions, but we
componenttext: Sure, I'm going to start. So Kent, this is Dan Matte. There's a couple of things. So one, with the virtual additions themselves, we are going to be increasing the performance. We think we already have great performance within our virtual additions, but we'll crank that up even more. Another aspect that we're working on, too, is allowing people to string multiple versions of those together and act as one coherent unit, too. So as we think about many of these larger players and thinking about having a totally software-defined data center, if you will, so everything looks the same inside of it and you're changing the personality of the devices solely by software, we think that we've got a very interesting way to help them do that and utilize our software from that perspective. The other piece that I mentioned, too, is different go-to-market models as well. So we think there are other ways to exploit and take -- better get our products into what I've called the serverless generation. So people coming up with new companies who are not likely to build their own data centers or purchase servers or anything like that. They are just going to be renting infrastructure from various players out there. So I want to make sure we've got that covered. And then also we recognize that people have different ways of adopting cloud technology. And whether they're doing it internally in private clouds or as I've said, the serverless generation purely in a public or those in between, with hybrid. So we definitely have technology coming that allows people to use as much or as little of both of those or simultaneously use both as they would like and make it seamless so that the cloud is just another resource that they're able to draw upon.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned the high attach of software modules. Is that at a level that you think it's where it's going to be, or do you think with the coming product sets that, that's -- that you could see higher attach going forward?
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned the high attach of software modules. Is that at a level that you think it's where it's going to be, or do you think with the coming product sets that, that's -- that you could see higher attach going forward?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we can see higher attach. It's a number of things. I mean, I mentioned security, the application firewall is a very good example in the access policy manager for access. They have 2 very, very strong momentum modules right now. But as we add more
componenttext: I think we can see higher attach. It's a number of things. I mean, I mentioned security, the application firewall is a very good example in the access policy manager for access. They have 2 very, very strong momentum modules right now. But as we add more modules, like DPI, like the bigger function firewall that's coming, I think you'll see a more module connect. And then the another thing that's critical is sales execution in this area, sales in SE and service execution, where not just -- we started off with North America being the leader, but we're now seeing areas like Japan, the rest of APAC, Europe, also doing extremely well with the modules and realizing it's a differentiator. And then the fact that we have our VIPRION chassis solutions that are ideal for building more and more modules on the one platform. So I do -- I think it's the right strategy, and it should increase the attach rate.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ryan Hutchinson with Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: I have somewhat of a follow up on just the overall security strategy. And, John, you touched on in the prepared remarks, maybe it's a question for Dan or Erik, if he's there. But I just wanted to understand where we're headed here. You clearly are looking
componenttext: I have somewhat of a follow up on just the overall security strategy. And, John, you touched on in the prepared remarks, maybe it's a question for Dan or Erik, if he's there. But I just wanted to understand where we're headed here. You clearly are looking to build out a comprehensive solution. You're covering some aspects of it, but I just want to get a -- where are we in 12 to 24 months, or do we cover network protocol app and access security? And is project Topaz -- does that fulfill the needs, or is there more to come beyond that? And I guess the real question is, who ultimately are we going to be competing with?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, so this is Manny Rivelo. So, Ryan, let me answer that question. There are a couple of things. First of all, we have 2 major use cases, if you will. One of them is really around what I would call unified access. And around unified access is the whole
componenttext: Yes, so this is Manny Rivelo. So, Ryan, let me answer that question. There are a couple of things. First of all, we have 2 major use cases, if you will. One of them is really around what I would call unified access. And around unified access is the whole concept of ensuring that we know who the user is, and we contextually can create an identity of that user, identifying the who, what, when, where and how of what that user is trying to do and then enable him to access those services, whether they be on network or off network. So that's a very strong use case. We've been gaining a lot of market share there. And just recently, it was reported by Infonetics where we moved to the position #2 from a market share perspective. The other use case that we've been working a lot, which is around project Topaz, is really a web firewall defending your applications. And that is a layer 3 to layer 7 firewall technology, high performance, high throughput, high connection count, high, high concurrent connections. And what that basically has is everything from layer 3 DDoS protection, all the way to application vulnerability protection, all wrapped up in one solution set. And that, by all means, is a product that we currently have in the market, widely successful with that market, and we're going to continue to create further integration with project Topaz in the next software release. So if you think about the competitors across those 2 different markets. On one end, we're competing against identity bridges and vendors of that size and in the data center firewall, we'll compete against Juniper, Cisco, Palo Alto. But to be perfectly frank, none of those companies have focused on a web solution set. So although they are competitors, they're not really the right solution in the market at this time.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2012
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'll add, you asked a question about the next 12 to 24 months. Obviously, this is a starting point. We got other areas we're going to [indiscernible]. We have some other significant things we're building into the platform itself, such as l
componenttext: The other thing I'll add, you asked a question about the next 12 to 24 months. Obviously, this is a starting point. We got other areas we're going to [indiscernible]. We have some other significant things we're building into the platform itself, such as like DDoS adding significantly to our hardware capabilities there. A lot of security features in ASM, things in the future, we're looking at malware prevention. There's a lot of vectors [ph] that we can go after. But once we have this footprint, this capability and this performance, that's the big enabler.

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2012 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections please describe it at this time.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Victor. Welcome to all of you to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2012. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, the Executive VP and CFO will speak to today's call. Other members of our executive team
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Victor. Welcome to all of you to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2012. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, the Executive VP and CFO will speak to today's call. Other members of our executive team are also does to answer questions following John and Andy's comments.
If you have questions following today's call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release, you can access one on our website at f5.com.
In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events calendar page of our website through January 23, from 4:30 p.m. today until midnight Pacific Time July 19, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (888) 568-0394, (203) 369-3916.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in the quarterly press release and described in detail in our SEC filings. Before we begin, I want to remind you that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Before we begin the call, I want to remind you that we are holding our 2012 Analyst Investor Meeting in New York on November 15. If you are planning to attend a meeting and you have not registered we invite you to register online through the link on our IR Events Calendar entry for November 15. We hope you can join us in New York for that event.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. F5's fiscal 2012 was a year of solid execution in a difficult macroeconomic environment. We were able to achieve 20% revenue growth, maintain world-class operating margins and delivered record earnings and cash flow, while developing prod
componenttext:
Thank you, John. F5's fiscal 2012 was a year of solid execution in a difficult macroeconomic environment. We were able to achieve 20% revenue growth, maintain world-class operating margins and delivered record earnings and cash flow, while developing products and services that set the stage for several years of continued revenue growth. Following discussion of results for the fourth quarter and for fiscal year 2012, we will provide guidance for Q1 2013 and outline our general planning assumptions and expectations for the year.
As a reminder, all non-GAAP numbers excludes stock-based compensation expense and amortization of purchased intangible assets. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP results is included with our press release.
For the fourth quarter of 2012, revenue of $362.6 million was within our guided range of $360 million to $370 million, up 3% from the prior quarter and 15% from the fourth quarter a year ago. Book-to-bill for the quarter was equal to 1. Before our product revenue of $209.7 million, up 6% from the fourth quarter of last year represented 58% of revenue.
Reversed revenue of $152.8 million increased 30% year-over-year and accounted for 42% of revenue. Before revenue from our core Application Delivery Networking business was $356.8 million and revenue from our ARX file virtualization business was $5.8 million.
On a regional basis, the Americas grew 8% year-over-year and represented 56% of revenue. EMEA, representing 22% of overall revenue, grew 29%. APAC at 15% of revenue, grew 31% and Japan, 7% of revenue, grew 13% from a year ago.
By vertical, telco represented 19% of sales during the quarter. Technology, 17% and financial, 20%. Total government was 17% of sales, including 10% from U.S. federal.
During Q4, we had 2 greater than 10% distributors, Avnet Technologies, which accounted for 16.8% of total revenue; and Ingram Micro, which represented 12.8%.
Continuing down the income statement, GAAP gross margin in Q4 was 82.7%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 84%. Operating expenses of $188 million were at the low end of our $188 million to $195 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $164.6 million.
GAAP operating margin was 30.8% non-GAAP operating margin was 38.6%. Other income for the quarter was $900,000.
The company's GAAP and non-GAAP net income for the quarter reflect a higher than expected effective tax rate. This resulted from a higher than expected impact of foreign permanent tax differences and a higher blended effective state tax rate, which increased our GAAP effective tax rate for the fourth quarter to 39.9%, above our expectation of 35.5%. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 37% above our 34% expectation. This higher than anticipated tax rates had an impact of approximately $0.06 to GAAP EPS and $0.05 to non-GAAP EPS.
Reflecting the higher tax rate for the quarter, GAAP net income for Q4 was $67.7 million or $0.85 per diluted share, below our guided range of $0.90 to $0.93. Non-GAAP net income was $88.7 million or $1.12 per diluted share also below our guided range of $1.16 to $1.19.
Revenue for all fiscal 2012 was $1.38 billion, up 20% from fiscal 2011. GAAP net income for fiscal 2012 was $275.2 million or $3.45 per diluted share. Non-GAAP net income was $348.6 million or $4.37 per diluted share.
Turning to the balance sheet. In Q4, we generated $148.6 million in cash flow from operations which contributed to cash and investments totaling $1.19 billion at year end. For all of fiscal 2012, cash flow from operations totaled $495 million.
DSO was 46 days. Inventory at the end of the quarter was $17.4 million. Deferred revenue increased 30% year-over-year to $447.3 million. Capital expenditures for the fourth quarter were $11.3 million.
During the quarter, we added 125 employees ending then the year with approximately 3,030 full-time employees. For the fiscal year, we added 540 employees an increase of 22%.
In Q4, we repurchased approximately 514,000 shares of our common stock at an average price of $97.29 per share for a total of $50 million. Approximately $180 million remains authorized under the current share repurchase program.
Moving on to our guidance for Q1 and our fiscal year '13 outlook. We are awaiting a number of factors is we determine guidance for Q1 and assess our growth prospects for fiscal year '13. As you have referenced several times over the year, we do anticipate typical fiscal Q1 seasonality. We also recognize that our short-term visibility continues to be limited by the macro economic uncertainty, which caused many of our customers to slow our reduced spending in the second half of fiscal 2012, particularly in the case of larger million dollar-plus type opportunities.
At the same time, we are anticipating a very positive perceptions of the new products and platforms that we will be introducing in fiscal 2013. Throughout the year, we are rolling out a powerful lineup of new hardware platforms, software products and significant performance increases to our virtual products that will drive new and increased growth for F5. We also see momentum building in customer engagements for our Diameter Signaling products and the traffic's acquisition and believe this will drive material revenue in fiscal year '13.
Lastly, we see a very real market share opportunity with the recent announcement from Cisco to cease development of its a's product line and we're being very aggressive in our efforts to capture this opportunity.
In consideration of these factors for the first quarter of fiscal 2013, we are targeting revenue in the range of $363 million to $370 million. We are forecasting GAAP gross margins to remains and 83% range, including approximately $3 million of stock-based compensation expense and $1 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
We estimate GAAP operating expense of $193.5 million to $198.5 million, including approximately $25.5 million of stock-based compensation expense. We anticipate a GAAP effective tax rate of 37% for the quarter and the non-GAAP effective tax rate of 34.5%.
The Q1 GAAP earnings target is $0.86 to $0.88 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $1.14 to $1.16 per share. We expect DSO in the mid- to high 40 range. We anticipate inventories in the range of $17 million to $19 million. We plan to increase our headcount by approximately 100 employees during the quarter. And we believe we will generate cash flow from operations in excess of $145 million.
For fiscal 2013, our general planning assumptions and expectations are as follows: We expect to see sequential revenue growth throughout the year with more robust product growth in the back half of the year as demand builds related to our forthcoming product refresh and new security and service providers software modules. We anticipate GAAP gross margins consistent with our Q1 guidance of 83%. We are targeting non-GAAP operating margins for the year to be at or around 38%, with some seasonal fluctuation is margins will be a bit lower in the first half and stronger in the second half.
We expect stock-based compensation expense to approximate Q1 levels until our next annual grant in August. Capital expenditures are expected to be $6 million to $12 million per quarter with some quarter-to-quarter variability related to investments.
Inconsistent with Q1, we expect our effective tax rates to average approximately 37% on a GAAP basis, 34.5% on the non-GAAP basis throughout the year. These tax assumptions do not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit.
As John mentioned, we will be holding our analyst investor meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York on November 15. We look forward to seeing you there. 
And with that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll take a few minutes to discuss F5's performance in fiscal 2012, talk in more detail about our Q4 results and then comment on our outlook and the exciting opportunities we see going at the fiscal 2013.I was
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll take a few minutes to discuss F5's performance in fiscal 2012, talk in more detail about our Q4 results and then comment on our outlook and the exciting opportunities we see going at the fiscal 2013.
I was very pleased with the F5 team's performance in fiscal 2012. In spite of a difficult macroeconomic environment, especially in the second half of the year, we achieved year-over-year revenue growth of 20% with world-class non-GAAP operating margins above 38%. We accomplished this while investing significantly in additional headcount increasing our tools and the headcount by 404 employees ending the year with a total of 3,030 employees. We exited fiscal 2012 with the stable of balance sheet with almost $1.2 billion in cash and investments and no debt, and repurchased $185 million of common stock during the year.
Sales of our VIPRION chassis-based products were particularly strong with year-over-year growth of 107% driven by strong adoption of the midrange VIPRION 2400 system, as well as sales of the high-end VIPRION systems into the service provider market.
In addition, our overall software sales increased by 58% driven by a significant increase in software module a tax rates and strong growth in sales of the software-only versions of our product portfolio. The growth in our softer tax rates clearly benefits our business model and is also critical to our market expansion strategy. We have made tremendous progress in expanding our opportunities into key markets, including security, service provider and cloud-based architectures.
In security, we now are the most comprehensive integrated solution in the industry that includes our application firewall, ESM, and our remote access solution, APM.
Software revenues from a security module with approximately $55 million last year, up 90% from the previous year. This is software-only revenue and doesn't include the service revenue the associated BIG-IP of VIPRION hardware incremental ADC revenue of any of the revenue from the data center firewall solution.
In the service provider market, our ability to deliver intelligent policy enforcement at world class performance levels, continues to be a key capability for managing the challenge of every expanding increase in mobile data. Our high-end VIPRION platform combined with the application fluency of TMOS and the flexibility of features like high rules, gives service providers a unique opportunity to build value-added services.
We also made good progress with sales, firewall IPv6 and traffic seeing solutions. I'm also very pleased with the progress we are making with the acquisition of Traffix Systems that was completed in mid-2012 the traffic Steve is world-class and the have them as part of our family as we mentioned last quarter we believe the opportunity where the traffic diameter base solutions will prove to be both significant and strategic to our overall service provider business. The traffic pipeline has been growing nicely. Our service providers rollout that LTE architectures and adopt Diameter as a standard signaling protocol. I'll talk more about this when I discuss our fiscal 2013 opportunities.
Our Services business delivered strong performance consistently throughout fiscal 2012, and continued to be a significant profit and revenue growth contributor while maintaining customer satisfaction at world class levels. The attach rate of service to product sales continues to improve and we once again experienced excellent renewal rates. We also continue to grow consulting business which increases customer satisfaction and drive additional product revenue. As far as Q4 is concerned, I'm very pleased with our results. We delivered 15% year-over-year growth in spite of a cautious spending environment. From a geographic perspective, both EMEA and Asia Pacific regions, have solid sales growth. In North America, we saw a reasonable sales growth for orders up to $1 million in size, but a drop-off in sales orders above $1 million as customers postponed last purchases or reduced the size of the purchase order. 
Overall, Q4 financial performance was very strong quarter the cash, free cash flow was over $137 million, a record for the company. And our non-GAAP operating margins remains solid at 38.6%. Our Services business completed the year with another strong quarter and a very healthy deferred revenue balance moving into fiscal 2013.
As far as the outlook is concerned, it is appropriate to be cautious given the very conservative spending environment we saw in the second half of fiscal 2012. Having said that, we believe we have a number of exciting opportunities coming in fiscal 2013 to drive our revenue growth and we plan to continue to invest in our business just to take advantage of those opportunities.
We increased our salesforce in 2012 by approximately 20% and we expect to see the benefits of this investment throughout the year. We have a clear and growing leadership position in the ADC market our goal is the continued expanding an addressable market and further increase our market share by developing a broad array of integrated solutions running on industry-leading platforms.
During the next 2 quarters, we will be delivering our largest appliance refresh in 4 years. Our next release of TMOS includes a number of new security and service provider operations as well as products to enable architectures. For example, we will be releasing the industry's first application delivery firewall, ADF, that integrates level 3 to level 7 security including DDoS prevention and unique application fluency to prevent sophisticated application attacks.
ADS provides performance metrics clearly superior to those offered by our competitors. We will also be delivering the industry's broadest range of hypervisor support at world class performance levels. For the service provider market, we will be delivering additional carrier grade NAT functionality and a new software module, as well as a policy enforcement module with EPI classification technology.
Additionally, we expect to release a new 8-swap of our VIPRION that will leverage the PB 300 blaze released last quarter, and effectively doubled the unmatched performance of VIPRION 4480, our current high-end platform.
As I mentioned earlier, we also expect to benefit from the rollout of LTE infrastructures with our Traffix Systems signaling delivery controller and Diameter solutions. The pipeline for these products is building steadily, and we're seeing a fairly large uptick in RFP and proof of concept requests. F5 has the opportunity to be a leader in this area which will not only provide growth opportunities over the next 3 years but should also significantly enhance our position as a strategic supplier to global service providers. We will review our product roadmap deliverables as well as our market initiatives in more detail at the Analyst Investor Meeting in November.
Andy provided our projected revenue range as well as some of the high-level expectations for fiscal 2013. As I mentioned several times over the last couple of years, we expect to see some seasonality in our business during Q1. The first quarter seasonality which is normal in the technology market and in landed our peers is reflected in our guidance.
Acceleration of product revenue growth is the major financial goal for fiscal 2013. I remain very optimistic about the future side as we enter fiscal 2013. We enjoy a very strong competitive position and I believe our fiscal 2013 product deliverables are the most comprehensive we have seen in several years. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank the entire F5 team and their partners for their tremendous efforts last year and I look forward to discontinue support in fiscal 2013.
And with that, will now hand the call over for Q&A.

componenttext: And John highlighted it if we have this full proxy capability into our device. When we orchestrated our technology, whether it be hardware or software, it has a layer of 7 full proxy which allows us to move through the protocol stack and then add additional services in 1 passthrough device, a session layer. That is significantly different than taking the traditional firewall than trying to apply layer 7 intelligence to it. So putting a load balancer firewall is a complicated issue. You almost have to have right platform from the foundation. What we've done is we've built the right platform starting with some availability services, and put security services in it. So we have a leadership position the data will prove that out of the announce it later and I think you'll see some performance characteristics that are just in order of magnitude greater than anything in the margin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks' Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2012 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections please disconnect at this time.I'd now like
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks' Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2012 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections please disconnect at this time.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Victor. Welcome to all of you to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2012. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, the Executive VP and Chief Financial Office will speakers on today's call. Other members
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Victor. Welcome to all of you to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2012. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, the Executive VP and Chief Financial Office will speakers on today's call. Other members of our executive team are also on hand to answer questions following John and Andy's prepared comments.
If you have followup questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com.
In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast in the Events Calendar page of our website through January 23, from 4:30 p.m. today until 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time on October 25, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (888) 568-0394, (203) 369-3916.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly release and described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Before we begin the call, I want to remind you that we are holding our 2012 Analyst Investor Meeting in New York on November 15. If you are planning to attend the meeting and have not registered, we invite you to register online through the link on our IR Events Calendar entry for November 15. We hope you can join us in New York for that event.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. F5's fiscal 2012 was a year of solid execution in a difficult macroeconomic environment. We were able to achieve 20% revenue growth, maintain world-class operating margins and delivered record earnings and cash flow, while developing prod
componenttext:
Thank you, John. F5's fiscal 2012 was a year of solid execution in a difficult macroeconomic environment. We were able to achieve 20% revenue growth, maintain world-class operating margins and delivered record earnings and cash flow, while developing products and services that set the stage for several years of continued revenue growth. Following discussion of results for the fourth quarter and for fiscal year 2012, we will provide guidance for Q1 2013 and outline our general planning assumptions and expectations for the year.
As a reminder, all non-GAAP numbers excludes stock-based compensation expense and amortization of purchased intangible assets. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP results is included with our press release.
For the fourth quarter of 2012, revenue of $362.6 million was within our guided range of $360 million to $370 million, up 3% from the prior quarter and 15% from the fourth quarter a year ago. Book-to-bill for the quarter was equal to 1. Q4 product revenue of $209.7 million, up 6% from the fourth quarter of last year represented 58% of revenue.
Service revenue of $152.8 million increased 30% year-over-year and accounted for 42% of revenue. Q4 revenue from our core Application Delivery Networking business was $356.8 million and revenue from our ARX file virtualization business was $5.8 million.
On a regional basis, the Americas grew 8% year-over-year and represented 56% of revenue. EMEA, representing 22% of overall revenue, grew 29%; APAC, at 15% of revenue, grew 31%; and Japan, 7% of revenue, grew 13% from a year ago.
By vertical, telco represented 19% of sales during the quarter; technology, 17%; and financial, 20%. Total government was 17% of sales, including 10% from U.S. federal.
During Q4, we had 2 greater than 10% distributors: Avnet Technologies, which accounted for 16.8% of total revenue; and Ingram Micro, which represented 12.8%.
Continuing down the income statement, GAAP gross margin in Q4 was 82.7%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 84%. Operating expenses of $188 million were at the low end of our $188 million to $195 million guided range. And non-GAAP operating expenses were $164.6 million.
GAAP operating margin was 30.8%. Our non-GAAP operating margin was 38.6%. Other income for the quarter was $900,000.
The company's GAAP and non-GAAP net income for the quarter reflect a higher than expected effective tax rate. This resulted from a higher than expected impact of foreign permanent tax differences and a higher blended effective state tax rate, which increased our GAAP effective tax rate for the fourth quarter to 39.9%, above our expectation of 35.5%. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 37% above our 34% expectation. This higher than anticipated tax rates had an impact of approximately $0.06 to GAAP EPS and $0.05 to non-GAAP EPS.
Reflecting the higher tax rate for the quarter, GAAP net income for Q4 was $67.7 million or $0.85 per diluted share, below our guided range of $0.90 to $0.93. Non-GAAP net income was $88.7 million or $1.12 per diluted share also below our guided range of $1.16 to $1.19.
Revenue for all fiscal 2012 was $1.38 billion, up 20% from fiscal 2011. GAAP net income for fiscal 2012 was $275.2 million or $3.45 per diluted share. Non-GAAP net income was $348.6 million or $4.37 per diluted share.
Turning to the balance sheet. In Q4, we generated $148.6 million in cash flow from operations, which contributed to cash and investments totaling $1.19 billion at year end. For all of fiscal 2012, cash flow from operations totaled $495 million.
DSO was 46 days. Inventory at the end of the quarter was $17.4 million. Deferred revenue increased 30% year-over-year to $447.3 million. Capital expenditures for the fourth quarter were $11.3 million.
During the quarter, we added 125 employees, ending then the year with approximately 3,030 full-time employees. For the fiscal year, we added 540 employees, an increase of 22%.
In Q4, we repurchased approximately 514,000 shares of our common stock at an average price of $97.29 per share for a total of $50 million. Approximately, $180 million remains authorized under the current share repurchase program.
Moving on to our guidance for Q1 and our fiscal year '13 outlook. We are awaiting a number of factors as we determine guidance for Q1 and assess our growth prospects for fiscal year '13. As we have referenced several times over the year, we do anticipate typical fiscal Q1 seasonality. We also recognize that our short-term visibility continues to be limited by the macro economic uncertainty, which caused many of our customers to slow or reduce spending in the second half of fiscal 2012, particularly in the case of larger million dollar-plus type opportunities.
At the same time, we are anticipating a very positive reception of the new products and platforms that we will be introducing in fiscal 2013. Throughout the year, we are rolling out a powerful lineup of new hardware platforms, software products and significant performance increases to our virtual products that will drive new and increased growth for F5. We also see momentum building in customer engagements for our Diameter Signaling products from the Traffix acquisition and believe this will drive material revenue in fiscal year '13.
Lastly, we see a very real market share opportunity with the recent announcement from Cisco to cease development of its ACE product line and we are being very aggressive in our efforts to capture this opportunity.
In consideration of these factors for the first quarter of fiscal 2013, we are targeting revenue in the range of $363 million to $370 million. We are forecasting GAAP gross margins to remain in the 83% range, including approximately $3 million of stock-based compensation expense and $1 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
We estimate GAAP operating expense of $193.5 million to $198.5 million, including approximately $25.5 million of stock-based compensation expense. We anticipate a GAAP effective tax rate of 37% for the quarter and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 34.5%.
Our Q1 GAAP earnings target is $0.86 to $0.88 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $1.14 to $1.16 per share. We expect DSO in the mid- to high-40-day range. We anticipate inventories in the range of $17 million to $19 million. We plan to increase our headcount by approximately 100 employees during the quarter. And we believe we will generate cash flow from operations in excess of $145 million.
For fiscal 2013, our general planning assumptions and expectations are as follows: We expect to see sequential revenue growth throughout the year with more robust product growth in the back half of the year as demand builds related to our forthcoming product refresh and new security and service providers software modules. We anticipate GAAP gross margins consistent with our Q1 guidance of 83%. We are targeting non-GAAP operating margins for the year to be at or around 38%, with some seasonal fluctuation is margins will be a bit lower in the first half and stronger in the second half.
We expect stock-based compensation expense to approximate Q1 levels until our next annual grant in August. Capital expenditures are expected to be $6 million to $12 million per quarter with some quarter-to-quarter variability related to investments.
Inconsistent with Q1, we expect our effective tax rates to average approximately 37% on a GAAP basis and 34.5% on the non-GAAP basis throughout the year. These tax assumptions do not assume a reinstatement of the R&D tax credit.
As John mentioned, we will be holding our Analyst Investor Meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York on November 15. We look forward to seeing you there. 
And with that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll take a few minutes to discuss F5's performance in fiscal 2012, talk in more detail about our Q4 results and then comment on our outlook and the exciting opportunities we see going at the fiscal 2013.I was
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I'll take a few minutes to discuss F5's performance in fiscal 2012, talk in more detail about our Q4 results and then comment on our outlook and the exciting opportunities we see going at the fiscal 2013.
I was very pleased with the F5 team's performance in fiscal 2012. In spite of a difficult macroeconomic environment, especially in the second half of the year, we achieved year-over-year revenue growth of 20% with world-class non-GAAP operating margins above 38%. We accomplished this while investing significantly in additional headcount increasing our total net headcount by 540 employees, ending the year with a total of 3,030 employees. We exited fiscal 2012 with a stable balance sheet with almost $1.2 billion in cash and investments and no debt, having purchased $185 million of our common stock during the year.
Sales of our VIPRION chassis-based products were particularly strong with year-over-year growth of 107% driven by strong adoption of the midrange VIPRION 2400 system, as well as sales of the high-end VIPRION systems into the service provider market.
In addition, our overall software sales increased by 58% driven by a significant increase in software module attach rates and strong growth in sales of the software-only versions of our product portfolio. The growth in our software attach rate clearly benefits our business model and is also critical to our market expansion strategy. We have made tremendous progress in expanding our opportunities into key markets, including security, service provider and cloud-based architectures.
In security, we now have the most comprehensive integrated solution in the industry that includes our application firewall, ESM; and our remote access solution, APM.
Software revenue from our security modules was approximately $55 million last year, up 90% from the previous year. This is software-only revenue and doesn't include the service revenue, the associated BIG-IP or VIPRION hardware, incremental ADC revenue or any of the revenue from the data center firewall solution.
In the service provider market, our ability to deliver intelligent policy enforcement at world-class performance levels continues to be a key capability for managing the challenge of every expanding increase in mobile data. Our high-end VIPRION platform combined with the application fluency of TMOS and the flexibility of features like iRules gives service providers a unique opportunity to build value-added services.
We also made good progress with sales of Carrier-grade NAT, firewall IPv6 and traffic-seeing solutions. I'm also very pleased with the progress we are making with the acquisition of Traffix Systems that was completed in mid-fiscal 2012 the Traffix team is world-class and we are proud to have them as part of the F5 family. 
As I mentioned last quarter, we believe the opportunity where the Traffix Diameter Base solutions will prove to be both significant and strategic to our overall service provider business. The Traffix pipeline has been growing nicely. Our service providers rollout their LTE architectures and adopt Diameter as a standard signaling protocol. I'll talk more about this when I discuss our fiscal 2013 opportunities.
Our Services business delivered strong performance consistently throughout fiscal 2012, and continued to be a significant profit and revenue growth contributor while maintaining customer satisfaction at world class levels. The attach rate of service to product sales continues to improve and we once again experienced excellent renewal rates. We also continue to grow a consulting business, which increases customer satisfaction and drives additional product revenue. As far as Q4 is concerned, I'm very pleased with our results. We delivered 15% year-over-year growth in spite of a cautious spending environment. From a geographic perspective, both EMEA and our Asia Pacific regions, have solid sales bookings growth. In North America, we saw a reasonable sales growth for orders up to $1 million in size, but a drop-off in sales orders above $1 million, as customers' postponed last purchases have reduced the size of the purchase order. 
Overall, our Q4 financial performance was very strong. Quarterly, cash, free cash flow was over $137 million, a record for the company. And our non-GAAP operating margins remained solid at 38.6%. Our Services business completed the year with another strong quarter and a very healthy deferred revenue balance moving into fiscal 2013.
As far as the outlook is concerned, it is appropriate to be cautious given the very conservative spending environment we saw in the second half of fiscal 2012. Having said that, we believe we have a number of exciting opportunities coming in fiscal 2013 to drive our revenue growth and we plan to continue to invest in our business to take advantage of those opportunities.
We increased our sales force in 2012 by approximately 20% and we expect to see the benefits of this investment throughout the year. We have a clear and growing leadership position in the ADC market. Our goal is the continue expanding our addressable market and further increase our market share by developing a broad array of integrated solutions running on industry-leading platforms.
During the next 2 quarters, we will be delivering our largest appliance refresh in 4 years. Our next release of TMOS includes a number of new security and service provider offerings, as well as products to enable cloud architectures. For example, we will be releasing the industry's first application delivery firewall, ADF, that integrates level 3 to level 7 security including DDoS prevention and unique application fluency to prevent sophisticated application attacks.
ADS provides performance metrics clearly superior to those offered by our competitors. We will also be delivering the industry's broadest range of hypervisor support at world-class performance levels. For the service provider market, we will be delivering additional Carrier-Grade NAT functionality and a new software module, as well as a policy enforcement module with DPI classification technology.
Additionally, we expect to release a new 8-slot version of our VIPRION that will leverage the PB300 blaze [ph] released last quarter, and effectively doubled the unmatched performance of VIPRION 4480, our current high-end platform.
As I mentioned earlier, we also expect to benefit from the rollout of LTE infrastructures with our Traffix System's signaling delivery controller and Diameter solutions. The pipeline for these products is building steadily, and we're seeing a fairly large uptick in RFP and proof of concept requests. 
F5 has the opportunity to be a leader in this area, which will not only provide growth opportunities over the next 3 years but should also significantly enhance our position as a strategic supplier to global service providers. We will review our product roadmap deliverables as well as our market initiatives in more detail at the Analyst Investor Meeting in November.
Andy provided our projected revenue range as well as some of the high-level expectations for fiscal 2013. As I mentioned several times over the last couple of years, we expect to see some seasonality in our business during Q1. The first quarter seasonality, which is normal in the technology market and in line with our peers, is reflected in our guidance.
Acceleration of product revenue growth is the major financial goal for fiscal 2013. I remain very optimistic about the future of F5 as we enter fiscal 2013. We enjoy a very strong competitive position and I believe our fiscal 2013 product deliverables are the most comprehensive we have seen in several years. 
I'd like to take this opportunity to thank the entire F5 team and our partners for their tremendous efforts last year and I look forward to their continued support in fiscal 2013.
And with that, will now hand the call over for Q&A.

componenttextpreview: I'm looking at the numbers, it looks like you had a huge U.S. Federal, up over 70%, but you're down in Financial vertical over 10%. Telecom was also down over 10% sequentially. You see, I'm trying to tie this together with a geographic commentary. Well, i
componenttext: I'm looking at the numbers, it looks like you had a huge U.S. Federal, up over 70%, but you're down in Financial vertical over 10%. Telecom was also down over 10% sequentially. You see, I'm trying to tie this together with a geographic commentary. Well, it looks like you had a good quarter everywhere but in the Americas, based on the numbers. Is this a function specifically of Financial's large deals your commentary weakening? And how much of this -- I know the numbers are still small with respect to Virtual Editions, but in our commentary you noted that there was big spike up, albeit, off a small base, but is that starting to have an impact on the revenues?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, all I know, I don't think the Virtual Edition is having any significant impact whatsoever. The numbers are great in terms of percentage growth, they're obviously pretty smaller in total. So I don't think that's an issue. We've spent a lot of t
componenttext: Yes. First, all I know, I don't think the Virtual Edition is having any significant impact whatsoever. The numbers are great in terms of percentage growth, they're obviously pretty smaller in total. So I don't think that's an issue. We've spent a lot of time on this after the quarter and, frankly, during the quarter. But we're pretty convinced, when we look at the spending patterns of the large Fortune 500 companies, generally, obviously, finances. The whole chunk of them was in the Fortune 500. But, generally, there is definitely a cautious spending environment. And as I said and when I was doing the introduction, the spending patterns were actually pretty reasonable if you compare $200K to $500K, $500K to $1 million year-over-year. However, and this is mainly in North America, because this is where most of our large [indiscernible] will tend to come from. When you get to the $1 million-plus deal, we definitely seen a -- saw a slowdown, I should say, in the quarter and, generally, in the second half.

componenttext: John, was that specific -- those big deals, are most of those concentrated in the financial vertical or is it really spread more broadly across your base? And I also got a question about the linearity of the quarter, if you could give us any insight on that.

componenttext: Okay. No, we're not really concentrated that much in financial. There are good examples of that, but not so much. Service provider definitely was lower, I mean, at 19%, that's really towards the low end where we saw some slowness there. But not specifically in financials.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then to linearity, Paul, really what we saw is what we've seen over the last 2 quarters, we're a little above 50%. We normally follow the 51st [ph] 2 months, 53rd month, the last 3 quarters have been a couple of points higher than that, but consistent
componenttext: And then to linearity, Paul, really what we saw is what we've seen over the last 2 quarters, we're a little above 50%. We normally follow the 51st [ph] 2 months, 53rd month, the last 3 quarters have been a couple of points higher than that, but consistent over the last 3 quarters.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012

componenttext: I have a couple of questions. I think number one, the verticals that you were discussing were both lumpy up and lumpy down, depending on the vertical. componenttext: In terms of the verticals, first of all, I guess, this is pretty obvious. But we feel very good about the team and the job they did and the relative year-over-year performance that we would expect as we see throughout the year. That's one thing. The second question was...

componenttext: Yes. We are actually assuming a relatively slow telco for the first -- for the next quarter. That could possibly bleed into the March quarter as well. But we're not talking about that yet. But definitely if we look forward to the guidance that we've given, we aren't expecting a strong service provider in Q1.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then to the sequential revenue growth, you're absolutely right. If we look back over time, in particular, going back 3, 4, 5 years, March probably has been our most difficult quarter just based on seasonality and that's led by North America. What we'v
componenttext: And then to the sequential revenue growth, you're absolutely right. If we look back over time, in particular, going back 3, 4, 5 years, March probably has been our most difficult quarter just based on seasonality and that's led by North America. What we've highlighted over the last couple of years is that we've really seen as we've grown to $1 billion and beyond that we've seen definite seasonality in our December quarter, which is our Q1. And so as we look at the layout over the year and we've highlighted and you see it in our guidance, our view in Q1, and we think off of that comparison we can grow in March now. But we're also highlighting that we think from a product basis, it will be stronger in the second half of the year versus the first half so.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the other point about that is that -- the really big deal for us, I think, is going to be the release of SOLA with the functionality we talked about, as well as the product refresh. We are absolutely -- we'll talk more about this in the Analyst Day t
componenttext: Yes, the other point about that is that -- the really big deal for us, I think, is going to be the release of SOLA with the functionality we talked about, as well as the product refresh. We are absolutely -- we'll talk more about this in the Analyst Day that's coming up, but we are, clearly, we're pushing very hard to get them available by the end of this calendar year. So if we achieve that, then I would expect to see some reasonably quick growth coming from that refresh, which would obviously head the March quarter.

componenttext: A couple of questions on the products. First, what was ARX's contribution in the quarter? And also what I think about big deals, immediately think VIPRION 4400, but your commentary seems to negate strengths also on the 4400, so can you talk about what the larger products in your portfolio are doing and are they still getting a digital module attach rate, more the chassis deployment issues?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, just on the last half there, as I mention, remember that a year-on-year number in terms of VIPRION sales. However, they have been pretty solid, quarterly rates throughout the year. And one of the characteristics we've definitely seen is a higher rate
componenttext: Yes, just on the last half there, as I mention, remember that a year-on-year number in terms of VIPRION sales. However, they have been pretty solid, quarterly rates throughout the year. And one of the characteristics we've definitely seen is a higher rate of module attach rate, which obviously drives the size of the system sale as well. The 2400 has just been strong from announcement, but the products above that, the VIPRION products above that, have also been strong, again, it was attach rate. Service provider, obviously, was a bit weaker last quarter, but that is definitely the main area that we sell the higher-end VIPRION and I think that's going to continue.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012

componenttext: A question around the product side. If you look at your guidance at the high-end of the range at $3.70 assuming 30% year-on-year services growth, which is what you've been doing there recently, implies about 5% product growth year-on-year. Can you talk about that and also how you see product sales doing through the year. You've talked earlier about seeing product growths, can you quantify that a little bit in terms of what you're thinking? Are you talking about something closer to your traditional kind of 15% to 20% range or something below that?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not going to quantify it, Brian. But just to give you an answer, so first of all, remember we're talking about the refresh coming towards the end of the calendar year. That's the target. That clearly wouldn't have a major impact on the first qu
componenttext: Yes. We're not going to quantify it, Brian. But just to give you an answer, so first of all, remember we're talking about the refresh coming towards the end of the calendar year. That's the target. That clearly wouldn't have a major impact on the first quarter. So that's one thing. Secondly, don't forget the seasonality issue. We don't want to be only company that's out there that does have seasonality. I wish we were, but we're not. There is seasonality in Q1, so that's taken into account. I feel, personally, very strongly that the product refresh, that the DPI functionality, what we're doing with the ADF, the application delivery firewall, is going to drive that product revenue, but given this environment we're in, we're not going through [ph] numbers out there. We're going to play a quarter at a time at the moment.

componenttext: Yes. If you look at -- I mean, the very fact that we talked about the VIPRION products over the year, been over 100% growth. The very fact we talked about the VIPRION 2400 being hot. I mean, almost, that means there are some issues there that we need to fix, at the appliance range from a competitor perspective. And that's what the whole appliance refresh is all about. So we feel really good about our VIPRION trends and the way they're going to continue.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the issue with Cisco, in terms of their announcement in the market, I think it's going to be very significant for us. And by the way, I'm not alone in the room here, everybody feels that. We did a North America quarterly business review on 1 day,
componenttext: Okay. On the issue with Cisco, in terms of their announcement in the market, I think it's going to be very significant for us. And by the way, I'm not alone in the room here, everybody feels that. We did a North America quarterly business review on 1 day, where we get to see the key management there, and they're very excited about it. I'm going to pass over to Dan, he can maybe give some more details. But we are in a praying position here, because a lot of these accounts tend to be larger accounts. They want to have a company that's very focused in this market with a great balance sheet and all that good stuff, and that's really us. So I think, Jay, you're going to hear us talking very, very favorable over that opportunity during the year.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Subu, this is Dan. So we're pursuing that very aggressively out in the field all around, on all regions. We've already seen a number of face-to-face meetings take place. We've had just lots of interest around it. Cisco is doing roughly $200 million in run
componenttext: Subu, this is Dan. So we're pursuing that very aggressively out in the field all around, on all regions. We've already seen a number of face-to-face meetings take place. We've had just lots of interest around it. Cisco is doing roughly $200 million in run rate per year in sales, plus they have a pretty significant install base over the year, starting local director and all products that they've had over time. So we've got some great incentives for our customers and partners. So we have our channel involved in this as well. And then, also, I think in the short term, it's important to know that the activities that Cisco have going together are purely of a reference in the nature. So there's always challenges with the sales force alignment, competition and then how incentive will level those people be. So our challenge with Cisco over time has been getting invited to the party. And if we do get invited, we do very, very well and clearly there are people that we're are at the party and are asking us to come and participate. So we're, as John said, very bullish on it.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me add one more other thing about this, I think it's exciting for us as an opportunity. This isn't just a bit replacing that base. It's not just about. This is about giving us this very significant opportunity to get into more Fortune 500 accounts and
componenttext: Let me add one more other thing about this, I think it's exciting for us as an opportunity. This isn't just a bit replacing that base. It's not just about. This is about giving us this very significant opportunity to get into more Fortune 500 accounts and sell much more than the current base we've got, because what we'll be replacing here is mostly load balancing type applications. We will then work with all our value-added stuff that we've got in TMOS: Security, optimization, the software module. So I think it's a much bigger opportunity than just replacing that base. And as I say, I think, you'll hear us talking about that in quarter rate -- calls throughout this year.
